comments.body: Unfortunately this too breaks binary compatibility on Scala 2.11.

I think the original intention was that E = Throwable (it has to be the same thing as in ExitCase.Error anyway), and we don't support Scalaz IO fully in its bifunctor adventures.

Not gonna miss it though - it's not like I wanted to do message-passing to `release` cases using `Throwable`s, so for me it means just less `(_)` in pattern matches.

On a side note, we might want to consider dropping `E` from `Bracket[F[_], E]` (we'll be able to use `@typeclass` for free syntax) and hard-wiring everything to `Throwable` ðŸ˜ƒ . I'm not convinced thus far that we'll be able to make any good use of that `E` parameter on `ExitCase`. I wonder if @LukaJCB has to say something in its defense ðŸ˜¸

The idea with that `Option[E]` was to support Haskell's interruption model where you send an `E` with your `cancel` signal.

You are right that the original intent was E = Throwable. We failed to support Scalaz with it however, plus our `cancel` does not take an `E`, so in polymorphic code this is useless.

So it's junk that we might as well remove.
Yep, no objections to removal :) I'm just not sure if we even need `E` on `Bracket`.

`Bracket` having an `E` is the same as `MonadError` having an `E`, even if that `E` is usually `Throwable`.

For `Sync` it makes sense to specialize it because if a `BSync` (bifunctor `Sync` ðŸ˜›) ever happens, the difference will be that `Sync` catches Throwables in `delay`, `suspend`, `map` and `flatMap`, so it has behavior related to `Throwable`. So a `Sync[F] <: BSync[F, Throwable]` wouldn't be just a type alias.

I don't like type classes with two type parameters to be honest.
However polymorphic code will usually use `Sync` anyway.
ðŸ‘ we added it to future proof for Scalaz, but they can't use it so, remove it is!
@LukaJCB so what if we removed `E` parameter from Bracket and ExitCase and forced things to `Throwable`?
